title: 107_hr2830
content: The "Voting Restoration Act" is the short title of this Act, which aims to restore voting rights. The Voting Restoration Act aims to restore voting rights by addressing disparities in voting eligibility for ex-felons across different states. Congress asserts its supervisory power over federal elections and highlights the importance of ensuring voting rights for all citizens. Approximately 2 percent of the adult population, or 3,900,000 Americans, are unable to vote due to felony convictions. The number of incarcerated individuals has increased significantly, with drug offenders making up a large portion of the prison population. In some states, federal offenders must obtain a Presidential pardon to regain their voting rights. Approximately one-third of women in prison are incarcerated for nonviolent drug offenses, with African-Americans disproportionately affected by racially disparate sentencing laws. Minorities, particularly African-American men, are disproportionately impacted by laws that strip felons of their right to vote. Congress should address these discrepancies to ensure all Americans have the right to vote in Federal elections. The purpose of this Act is to restore voting eligibility to individuals who have completed sentences for criminal offenses. The Act aims to restore voting rights to individuals who have served sentences for criminal offenses and encourage their involvement in community life. The Act aims to protect the right to vote and register to vote in federal elections. The Act protects the voting rights of individuals with felony convictions, allowing restrictions only during custody or supervision. It also allows for a private right of action if violations occur, with a process for correction within specified timeframes. The Act allows individuals with felony convictions to protect their voting rights, with the option for a private civil action in court for violations occurring close to election dates. The Attorney General can also take legal action to address any necessary remedies. The Act allows for declaratory or injunctive relief to remedy violations, with the option for private civil action or legal action by the Attorney General. Grant program to assist states in protecting rights of ex-felons to vote and register in federal elections. Establishment of a grant program by the Attorney General to assist eligible States in protecting the voting rights of individuals convicted of felonies in federal elections. This program aims to provide information on eligibility to vote, increase voter registration rates, and states must meet specific requirements to receive grants. The Attorney General establishes a grant program to help States protect voting rights of felons in federal elections. States must apply with required information and assurances, and the grant amount is based on the number of felons in the State compared to all eligible States. Each State receiving a grant under the program must provide information to felons regarding their voting rights and eligibility through a program that includes maintaining an index of felons under state custody or supervision. The State must inform individuals about their voting rights and eligibility, including those engaged in plea bargaining or convicted of a felony. Activities must be carried out to notify individuals of their right to vote. Each State receiving a grant under the program must inform individuals of their right to vote, including those with felony convictions, through various means such as media, Internet, and cooperative agreements. States must report to the Attorney General on the activities conducted and the number of individuals informed of their voting rights. The program aims to reduce the number of felonies leading to the loss of voting rights. Each State receiving a grant under the program must establish an index of eligible felons to increase voter registration rates among them. The program aims to reduce felonies leading to disenfranchisement. The program aims to increase voter registration rates among individuals convicted of felonies by at least 50% over a 5-year period. States must also work to increase the voting participation of these individuals in elections by collaborating with public and private entities that provide services to felons. States receiving grants under the program must report activities to the Attorney General, including the number of convicted felons registered to vote and voting percentages. The Attorney General provides technical assistance to help states implement the program. An annual report is submitted to Congress detailing program activities and state-provided information. Authorization of appropriations for grants under the program for the first 5 fiscal years after the enactment of the Act is provided by the Attorney General. SEC. 5. Responsibilities of Department of Justice regarding individuals convicted of federal felonies. The Attorney General will maintain an index of individuals convicted of federal felonies under federal custody or supervision. They must inform individuals of their right to vote during plea bargaining and upon conviction, release, or completion of supervision. Additionally, a report must be submitted to Congress annually. The Attorney General must submit an annual report to Congress detailing activities related to informing individuals of their right to vote, including the number and percentage of those informed. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as "chief election official," "election," "Federal office," and "State." SEC. 7. RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. SEC. 7. RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. This Act does not affect eligibility to vote in non-Federal elections. The rights and remedies provided by this Act are in addition to those under the Voting Rights Act and National Voter Registration Act, without superseding or limiting them.
